bug.short_desc: vacation: subject decoded but not reencoded

long_desc.thetext:
I noticed a problem with non ASCII chars in a Subject of a message, which is automatically answered by sieve/vacation. Vacation reuses the original Subject line, but decodes the MIME in it and sends out the decoded (8bit) subject without reencoding it.
So a message with "Subject: =?iso-8859-1?Q?T=E4st?=" (correct quoted printable MIME encoding) is answered with "Subject: Täst" (8bit without any MIME encoding).
Wouldn't it be better to simply reuse the original Subject without any decoding? Otherwise the decoded Subject needs to be newly MIME encoded, doesn't it?

Thanks a lot Rob! ;)
I'm not sure that we have access to the original subject. IIRC the headers are decoded so we can do string comparisons on them. I'll have to double check.

;)
Right, well we might need to either carry it around somehow or reencode it.

I can't reproduce this on either of 2.1.14 or 2.2. AFAICT, the only time that headers are MIME decoded are when we construct cyrus.cache (for searching, etc). Sieve uses the raw headers from the message. This problem _might_ be caused by the MTA or mailer, but NOT Cyrus/Sieve. Closing bug.

Sorry, forget this bug report. I'm an stupid idiot. I installed a vacation script, which created the same Subject as the test mail, so I thought, that the Subject was recycled from the test mail, but it was created from the sieve script.
So there is no bug in Cyrus, but in my sieve script, which didn't encode the Subject.
